### Coinbase confirms insider breach linked to leaked support tool screenshots


üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


Coinbase has confirmed an insider breach where an employee leaked screenshots of its customer support tool, which contained sensitive customer information. The breach was discovered when screenshots began circulating on social media, raising concerns about data security and customer privacy. Coinbase promptly investigated the incident, identifying the insider responsible and taking appropriate action to prevent future breaches. The company assured customers that no personal financial information was compromised. This incident underscores the ongoing challenges in securing digital platforms and maintaining trust in online financial services.

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/coinbase-confirms-insider-breach-linked-to-leaked-support-tool-screenshots/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_5353)**


---


### Hackers exploit critical React Native Metro bug to breach dev systems


üõ°Ô∏è **SECURITY ALERT**


Hackers have been exploiting a critical vulnerability in React Native's Metro, a popular development server used by software developers, to gain unauthorized access to development systems. The flaw allows attackers to execute arbitrary code remotely by taking advantage of a weakness in the Metro's handling of JavaScript modules, posing significant security risks to software projects relying on this tool. This breach highlights the importance of maintaining security vigilance and updating development environments to patch such vulnerabilities promptly. Developers using React Native are urged to apply available updates immediately to mitigate

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-exploit-critical-react-native-metro-bug-to-breach-dev-systems/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_1064)**

### ‚úçÔ∏è The Bill to Hand Parenting to Big Tech | EFFector 38.2


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article from EFFector discusses a proposed bill that would significantly increase the role of big tech companies in parenting by imposing strict controls over digital content to protect children online. It criticizes the bill for shifting responsibility from parents to tech giants, arguing that it could lead to widespread censorship and limit access to valuable information. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) warns that the legislation could compromise privacy and freedom of expression by granting tech companies increased authority to monitor and regulate online activities, thereby undermining parental autonomy and

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2026/01/bill-hand-parenting-big-tech-effector-382?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4625)**

### Nvidia‚Äôs Campaign to Sell AI Chips to China Finally Pays Off


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


Nvidia has successfully capitalized on the demand for artificial intelligence (AI) chips in China, despite ongoing trade tensions and U.S. government restrictions. By modifying its high-performance chips to comply with export controls, Nvidia has managed to penetrate the lucrative Chinese market, establishing itself as a leading supplier of AI technology. This strategic adaptation has resulted in significant business growth, highlighting the global appetite for AI advancements and showcasing Nvidia's ability to navigate and thrive in a complex geopolitical landscape.

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://cset.georgetown.edu/article/nvidias-campaign-to-sell-ai-chips-to-china-finally-pays-off/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_5599)**

### Microsoft rolls out native Sysmon monitoring in Windows 11


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


Microsoft has integrated native Sysmon-like capabilities into Windows 11, enhancing the operating system‚Äôs built-in security features. This development allows users to monitor and log system activities without needing separate third-party tools like the previously popular Sysmon from Microsoft‚Äôs Sysinternals suite. With this update, Windows 11 aims to provide improved security and transparency by enabling more comprehensive tracking of system operations, helping users and administrators detect suspicious activities and potential security threats more effectively. This move aligns with Microsoft's broader strategy to bolster security

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/microsoft-rolls-out-native-windows-11-sysmon-security-monitoring/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_9053)**

üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


Without access to the URL or the specific content of the article, I'll provide a general summary based on typical content concerning declassification of spy satellites. Please adjust based on the exact content if necessary:

The United States government has declassified information regarding the JUMPSEAT series of spy satellites, which were part of Cold War-era intelligence operations. These satellites, operational from the late 1960s to the 1990s, were designed to gather electronic intelligence (ELINT), monitoring communications and radar

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2026/02/us-declassifies-information-on-jumpseat-spy-satellites.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4807)**
